title: Sir Thomas Halsey, 3rd Baronet
text:
Sir Thomas Edgar Halsey, 3rd Baronet <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">DSO</a> (28 November 1898 – 30 August 1970) was an English <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er, naval officer (1916–1946), and <a href="Deputy%20Lieutenant">Deputy Lieutenant</a> of <a href="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>.
A right-handed <a href="batsman">batsman</a> and right-arm <a href="Fast%20bowling">fast</a> <a href="Bowler%20%28cricket%29">bowler</a>, he played <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> between 1920 and 1928 and also represented the <a href="Egypt%20national%20cricket%20team">Egypt national cricket team</a>.
Early life.
Born in <a href="South%20Mimms">South Mimms</a> in 1898, Halsey was the elder son of <a href="Sir%20Walter%20Halsey%2C%202nd%20Baronet">Sir Walter Halsey, 2nd Baronet</a>, and his wife Agnes Marion, the daughter of William Macalpine Leny. He was educated at <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a> and <a href="Jesus%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Jesus College, Cambridge</a>. He was already a lieutenant in the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> when he went up to Cambridge.
Cricketer.
Halsey was a right-handed <a href="batsman">batsman</a> and right-arm <a href="Fast%20bowling">fast</a> <a href="Bowler%20%28cricket%29">bowler</a>.
He played cricket for Eton in 1915 and 1916, but it was for the <a href="Royal%20Navy%20Cricket%20Club">Royal Navy cricket team</a> that he made his first-class debut, playing against his university side during the <a href="1920%20English%20cricket%20season">1920 English cricket season</a>.
He played twice for the <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Cricket%20Club">university cricket team</a> in 1920, but did not gain his <a href="Blue%20%28university%20sport%29">blue</a>. The rest of his first-class matches were all for the Royal Navy, mostly against the <a href="British%20Army%20cricket%20team">British Army cricket team</a>, though there were also matches against the <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force%20cricket%20team">RAF</a> and <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20cricket%20team">New Zealand</a>.
He began to play <a href="Minor%20counties%20of%20English%20cricket">minor counties</a> cricket for <a href="Hertfordshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Hertfordshire</a> in 1921, continuing to play for them until 1932, a year in which he played for the Navy against <a href="South%20American%20cricket%20team%20in%20England%20in%201932">a combined South America team</a>. In 1936, he played for <a href="Egypt%20national%20cricket%20team">Egypt</a> against <a href="Hubert%20Martineau">HM Martineau's XI</a>, <a href="Captain%20%28cricket%29">captaining</a> the side and scoring a <a href="Century%20%28cricket%29">century</a> in the first <a href="Innings%20%28cricket%29">innings</a>.
Naval officer.
He was appointed a Companion of the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">Distinguished Service Order</a> (DSO) on 7 June 1940 "for good services in the withdrawal of the Allied Armies from the beaches at <a href="Dunkirk%20evacuation">Dunkirk</a>".
County officer.
Halsey retired from the Navy with the rank of captain in 1946, and went on to serve as <a href="Deputy%20Lieutenant">Deputy Lieutenant</a> for <a href="Hertfordshire">Herts</a> from 1948, a <a href="Justice%20of%20the%20Peace">JP</a> from 1950, <a href="County%20council">County Councillor</a> from 1953, and <a href="Lord%20Lieutenant">Vice-Lieutenant</a> for <a href="Hertfordshire">Herts</a> from 1957 until his death at <a href="Hemel%20Hempstead">Hemel Hempstead</a> in 1970.
Marriage and children.
Halsey married Jean Margaret Palmer, daughter of <a href="Bertram%20Willes%20Dayrell%20Brooke">Bertram Brooke</a>, onetime <a href="Tuan%20Muda%20of%20Sarawak">Tuan Muda of Sarawak</a>, and through him, granddaughter of the second <a href="White%20Rajahs">White Rajah</a> of <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Sarawak">Sarawak</a>, <a href="Charles%20Brooke%2C%20Rajah%20of%20Sarawak">Charles Brooke</a>. They had one son and two daughters.
